sentence: Benchmarks finished mostly in the red on Tuesday following a horrific terrorist attack in Brussels.
The deadly terror attack had a negative impact on travel and consumer staples stocks.
While the Dow and the S&P 500 closed in the red, the Nasdaq managed to end in the green following gains in Apple.
The tech-laden index posted its five straight session winning streak since April 2015.

For a look at the issues currently facing the markets, make sure to read today's Ahead of Wall Street article

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) decreased only 0.2%, to close at 17,582.57.
The S&P 500 also fell only 0.1% to close at 2,049.80.
However, the tech-laden Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 4,821.66, gaining 0.3%.
The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) increased more than 2.8% to settle at 14.17.
A total of around 6.2 billion shares were traded on Tuesday, significantly lower than the last 20-session average of 8.14 billion shares.
Decliners outpaced advancing stocks on the NYSE.
For 51% stocks that declined, 45% advanced.
Belgium's capital Brussels encountered terrorist attacks on Tuesday.
Two explosions hit the Zaventem airport and another explosion occurred at a Belgian metro train station which killed at least 35 and wounded more than 200 people.
The Islamic State (IS) had taken responsibility of this attack following arrest of a Paris bombing suspect last Friday.
The attack had a negative impact on the broader markets, with the transport and consumer staples stocks suffered the most.
The Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLP) declined 0.6% and was the biggest decliner among the S&P 500 sectors.

Key consumer staples stocks including Mondelez International, Inc. ( MDLZ ), Procter & Gamble Company ( PG ), Philip Morris International, Inc. ( PM ), Altria Group Inc. ( MO ), Costco Wholesale Corporation ( COST ) and Colgate-Palmolive Co. ( CL ) fell 1.9%, 0.7%, 1.9%, 1.2%, 1.1% and 1.2%, respectively.
The attack in Belgium also dragged transport related stocks down.
The Dow Jones Transportation Average (DJT) fell 0.8%.

Key holdings including American Airlines Group Inc. ( AAL ), Union Pacific Corporation ( UNP ), Ryder System, Inc. ( R ) and Kirby Corporation ( KEX ), declined 1.6%, 2.3%, 1.3%, 1.5% and 1.4%, respectively.
Also, the US Global Jets ETF (JETS) fell 1.1%.
Its key components including Delta Air Lines, Inc. ( DAL ), United Continental Holdings, Inc. ( UAL ) and Carnival Corporation ( CCL ) decreased 1.5%, 1.1% and 2.1%, respectively.
U.S. crude price also slumped following the Brussels attack.
The WTI crude decreased 0.2% to $41.45 a barrel on Tuesday.
However, global crude price ended in the green after OPEC's secretary-general Abdalla Salem el-Badri confirmed participation of major oil producing nations in the Doha meeting.
The Brent crude rose 0.6% to $41.79 per barrel.
Additionally, financial services stocks stumbled yesterday after low interest rates in the U.S. and negative interest rates in Europe raised concerns about banks' balance sheets.
The Financial Services Select Sector SPDR (XLFS) declined 0.4%.
Top holdings from the sector such as Bank of America Corporation ( BAC ), JPMorgan Chase & Co ( JPM ) and Wells Fargo & Company ( WFC ) fell 0.6%, 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively.
Dow component, Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. ( GS ) also declined more than 1.3% and was the biggest decliner in the blue-chip index.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq managed to end in the green after shares of Apple Inc. ( AAPL ) increased 0.8% following a court hearing against Apple was cancelled.
The U.S. Justice Department stated that the San Bernardino gunman's iPhone might be unlocked without Apple's help, which led to the cancellation of the court hearing.
